subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species is similar to
P. elongatus
and
P. occidentalis
, but distinct from the former for the costate elytra, lacking tubercles, and supraorbital carina only slightly raised; from the latter for the supraorbital carina weakly sinuate and pronotum indistinctly sculptured with a very shallow groove along anterior edge.

Head transverse; supraorbital carina raised, weakly sinuate; supra-antennal carina not raised and edge entire, not indented; eyes protruding with short, squamiform interfacetal setae; angulate protrusion between antennal insertion and eye, visible in lateral view; antennal insertion ventral, just below the edge of supra-antennal carina; antennae 11 -segmented with a distinct 3 -segmented club; antennomeres I–III subcylindrical; I and III about twice as long as II; IV–VIII very short and simple; IX–XI distinctly transverse to form a compact club.

Pronotum slightly transverse (pronotal length/width: 0.81–0.83 ), narrower than elytra, without prominent median process; margins smooth; maximum width at middle, with one angulate lobe, directed anteriorly; sculpture as in
Fig. 2
h, with a shallow groove along anterior edge.
Elytra about twice as long as wide (elytral length/width: 1.91–2.09 ), with lateral margins straight and smooth; tubercles on elytra absent; 3 rd, 5 th and 7 th intervals weakly costate.

Distribution and habitat occurrence. SW Western Australia , SE South Australia , Tasmania, New South Wales , Australian Capital Territory and SE Queensland (
Fig. 10
a); open forest.
